newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan parliament approves new company law.
newsitem.headline: Jordan parliament approves new company law.

text.p: Jordan's parliament has approved a new company law which cancels a 15 percent tax on companies raising their capital bases by transferring money from reserves, officials said on Thursday.

They said parliament approved on Wednesday the new companies law, part of a new package of economic reforms that is also expected to include a new customs law, a securities law, and a law to protect local industry from dumping.
The companies' law has to be sent for approval to parliament's upper chamber, the Senate, before it is enacted as a royal decree.

Prices in Jordan's blue-chip shares rose two weeks ago when parliament approved the section of the law scrapping the tax on capital raises. A number of leading companies have promised shareholders they intend to boost their capital with transfers from reserves, including free share offers, once the law was passed in its entirety.
Investment analysts say the move will also increase the supply of stock in firms that have currently reached a maximum foreign ownership ceiling.
The new law also scraps the state's issuing committee, which sets prices of new share issues.
